description.narrative: 1. Availability of educational policy on Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) for population 2. description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

The objective of the project is to reverse the existing trends and reduce consumption of electrical and thermal energy and associated greenhouse gas emissions in new and restored, primarily residential buildings in Armenia
Improving Energy Efficiency in Buildings
populated place

activity-description.narrative: Reduce consumption of energy and emissions in buildings

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Reduce consumption of energy and emissions in buildings

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Reduce consumption of energy and emissions in buildings

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: Reduce consumption of energy and emissions in buildings

description.narrative: Energy - power generation
Global Development Objective: Reduce GHG emissions and energy consumption in the Armenian residential building sector
Average thermal energy consumption for space heating in new residential buildings in Armenia.

comment.narrative: 185 kWh/m2 year
111 kWh/m2 year

Energy performance of the Goris pilot building from 216kWh/m2 year in baseline design was reduced to 82kWh/m2 year
Energy performance of the pilot building in Avan from 178kWh/m2 year in baseline design was reduced to 74kWh/m2 year
Energy performance of the 2 building types at "Cascade Hills" residential complex consulted by the Project from 74kWh/m2 year in baseline design was reduced to 47kWh/m2 year for 5 single section buildings and from 69kWh/m2 year in baseline design was reduced to 44kWh/m2 year for 1 double section building.

description.narrative: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new residential buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) against the baseline

comment.narrative: Zero reductions below business as usual (BAU) scenario.
Approx. 54 ktCO2eq reduced compared to the BAU scenario

Level at 30 June 2014 - about 10.52 ktCO2 was reduced compared to BAU scenario
Cumulative lifetime (20 years) CO2 emission reductions from new residential buildings built during project lifetime (as of 2014) -54.3 ktCO2

description.narrative: Design and enforcement of new EE Building Codes and Standards
Number of revised construction legal acts aimed at EE improvement in buildings.

comment.narrative: Codes for residential buildings are limited in energy performance to minimal hygienic norms.
By end of project, new codes adopted, setting mandatory energy performance targets comparable with CIS building codes (MSN) and/or EU standards.

Packages of legislation amendments in the Laws of the Republic of Armenia drafted by the project are currently circulated in the Government of Armenia by the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources and Ministry of Urban Development including: â€œOn making an amendment and an addition into the RA law â€œOn energy efficiency and renewable energyâ€; â€œOn making an addition into the RA law â€œOn urban developmentâ€; â€œOn developing the smaller center of Yerevanâ€.
Project ensured inclusion of energy efficiency mandatory and voluntary provisions in the Law on Smaller Center of Yerevan City , in particular - the minimal energy performance of 80 kWh/m2 year, which will come into force consequently after adoption of technical regulation on safety of buildings and structures. The approval of technical regulation on safety of buildings, constructions, materials and prefabricate is pending.
Harmonization of EU building energy performance directive and supporting six standards is elaborated; the standards are approved by the order N40-V of September 17, 2014, of National Institute of Standards CJSC of the RA Ministry of Economy and enacted on November 1, 2014. Based on the EU Directive the Technical regulation on buildings' energy efficiency is developed, circulated within stakeholders and submitted to the Government for approval.
Energy rating standard "Green building. Buildings and Civil Construction. Rating Evaluation of Sustainability in Building Construction" translation into Armenian completed, localization underway, based on the statement of intent between UNDP and â€œArmenian association of developersâ€ NGO.
Ministry of Urban Development of Armenia as a signatory of Interstate Building Code on Thermal Protection of Buildings is still waiting the updated document to be provided from Intergovernmental Scientific-technical Commission for Construction for consideration. However the development of the new code based on the previous version from 2004 is underway.
The charter of the Ministry of Urban Development was amended with provisions on ensuring the energy efficiency in construction sector according to the draft proposed by the Project.

description.narrative: Standards and methodology for assessing energy performance in buildings.

comment.narrative: Lack of methodology for assessing energy performance in buildings

By the project midterm, audit protocols are in place
By the project mid-term, guidelines for energy passport are drafted and approved
By the end of the project, audits are carried out in at least 50% of new buildings and buildings undergoing capital reconstruction
By the end of the project, energy passports provided for at least 50% of new buildings and buildings undergoing capital reconstruction.

National Standard "Energy efficiency. Building energy passport. Main provisions. Typical forms" was drafted and submitted to the National Institute of Standards for audit and registration, passed the "Energy sector" technical commission and approved on November 12, 2013 (registration ID: AST 362-2013). Energy passports for about 8 buildings are prepared based on this standard.
Draft national standard for Energy Audit Methodology in Buildings is discussed and finalised.

description.narrative:
Capacity of the MUD inspectorate and independent technical supervision bodies to implement and check compliance with energy efficiency codes
Integration of EE requirements into state-funded construction and procurement activities.

comment.narrative:
Statistics on enforcement do not exist
EE requirements not included

By project mid-term, code enforcement program in place.
By end of project, revision process for codes carried out or underway.
By end of project, code enforcement program reaches 50% of new and reconstructed buildings.
By end of project, EE requirements factored into all state-funded construction and procurement activities

Energy efficiency related legal and institutional improvements in urban development sector as developed by the Project's experts are included into a number of legislative amendments approved by the Government, certain amendments are under consideration.
Energy efficient solutions for building envelopes are promoted via recommendations included in the Handbook of technical solutions (adopted by the order #343 of the Minister of Urban Development of November 6, 2013) and disseminated among Project beneficiaries.
Professional literature was procured and disseminated among sector professionals and relevant universities, including the database on insulation materials (developed and published) and the updated code on building climatology (published).

description.narrative: Quality control, testing and certification of EE materials and equipment
At least one laboratory to perform testing and certification of domestic and imported construction materials energy performance.

comment.narrative: Due to the negligible demand for the corresponding services, the laboratories have no incentives to obtain the modern equipment, thus no testing and certification of energy efficient materials is done in country.
By end of project, at least one laboratory can perform testing and certification of domestic and imported construction materials such as insulation, windows, doors, and heating systems.

One testing laboratory (first time in Armenia) was duly equipped, staff trained and its activities commenced.
Educational/testing laboratory was equipped in the Yerevan State University of Architecture and Construction. Opening ceremony of both laboratories held in March 2013.
The Project supports 2 newly established laboratories, in particular, 1. a manual on instrumental measurement of thermal technical parameters is developed and approved by the National University of Architecture and Construction of Armenia Foundation for organization of practical lessons on application of the equipment and instruments procured; the manual is published and distributed; 2. continuous consultations are provided to partner organization/testing and certification body Shincertificate LLC.

description.narrative: Increase in share of domestically produced energy efficient/insulation materials in the construction market.

comment.narrative: Domestically-produced energy efficient/insulation materials comprise about 5-10%
By end of project, domestically-produced energy efficient/insulation materials comprise at least 10-20% of the market.

To ensure the market share of certified domestically produced insulation materials and prefabricates, the Project: i) testing and certification of 4 eligible local insulation products; ii) supported development of 6 technical specifications (TU) and their registration in the National Institute of Standards for local producers and importers of materials; iii) handed conformity certificates to 8 eligible local insulation products and materials; iv) distributed the developed Database of Locally produced and Imported Construction and Insulation Materials available in local market (Armenian and English, 2013).
According to market survey domestically-produced energy efficient/insulation materials comprise about 45% of local market.

description.narrative: Outreach, training and education
Number of students trained and modules/courses delivered.

comment.narrative: IBDA concepts are not used in the country at present
By end of project, all graduating architecture and civil engineering students with an emphasis on residential buildings are aware of IBDA concepts.

Over 90 students were trained: i) during trainings and workshops on integrated building design approach, building codes and construction materials certification issues organized, in Yerevan State University of Architecture and Construction. ii) within a 6-day Summer Extension Course on Solar Architecture jointly organized with American University of Armenia. iii) students of American University of Armenia and sector specialists were trained by an invited expert, an international board member of the US Building Commissioning Association on Sustainability, Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED), Commissioning and their interconnection.
The complete set of ten educational modules on energy efficiency in buildings are developed (in Armenian and in English), compiled as a biligual textbook on Green Architecture to be further included in the curricula of the respective Universities (confirmation letter received) and published.

description.narrative: Number of practicing professionals trained, number of trainings delivered and public awareness raising campaigns conducted.

comment.narrative: IBDA concepts are not used in the country at present

By project mid-term, key experts at design institutes and in university are using IBDA concepts.
By end of project, at least 4-5 % of buildings constructed annually apply IBDA

About 180 sector professionals were trained during: i) study tour for Project stakeholders from Ministry of Urban development and Yerevan Municipality. ii) training for 40 sector professionals on building insulation techniques. iii) trainings and workshops on integrated building design approach, building codes and construction materials certification issues. iv) study tour on construction and insulation materials testing and certification in Research Institute of Building Physics, Moscow. v) study tour on materials testing and certification in companies of Germany. vi) Training of developers on voluntary rating standard and energy passports/energy efficiency labels for buildings in Armenia.
Project supports design and construction of buildings using Integrated Building Design Approach, in particular: i) 1 school using Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, ii) 1 multi-purpose building using Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design certificate scheme, iii) a 10 building residential complex in Yerevan. Designs of five replicable (typical) energy efficient individual residential houses for communities of Armenia and respective catalog were approved by Ministry of Urban Development, published on Ministry and Project websites, printed and distributed over Armenia.

description.narrative: Rate of application of the energy passport and label system by real estate developers and number of public awareness raising campaigns conducted.

comment.narrative: Energy passports and labels are not used

By project mid-term, a majority of real estate professionals are aware of the potential benefits of energy-efficient buildings and understand the energy passport and label.
By end of project, at least 10% of new residential building stock is marketed with energy passports and labels

Continuing the previous years' experience, 13 energy audits were conducted in residential buildings, from which 6 energy audits were performed based on instrumental measuring. Energy passports developed.
Series of three social ads (prepared in 2013) were amended with subtitles and broadcast via LED displays in Yerevan (in cooperation with Yerevan Municipality).
2 documentaries on Energy Efficiency: Saving and Comfort focusing on building energy efficiency situation in Armenia and Project activities and on opening of social demo building in Goris town were prepared, broadcast and shared on web.
Two newspaper articles on demonstration building in Yerevan city, one - on locally produced insulation materials certification were published as was an article on testing and certification laboratory established.
Several coverages of the story of pilot project in Avan were produced by local and international TV and media and Yerevan city municipality as the project's key partner.
Thematic calendar and other promotion materials designed and published.

description.narrative: Demonstrating integrated building design
Demonstration building thermal performance compared to the improved code and to the existing code.

comment.narrative: The standard building design used in housing developments may not comply with current building codes regarding thermal performance

By project mid-term, the building design is completed and approved by the developer and MUD.
By end of project, demonstration building showing at least 30% better thermal performance that the improved code and 60% better than the existing code

Energy performance of the pilot building in Goris town as commissioned in December 2012, performed during 2012-2013 and 2013-2014 heating seasons. Data collected and analysed, respective report created, shared with stakeholders and published.
Demonstration building in Avan, Yerevan city is reconstructed, commissioned and monitored during 2013-2014 and 2014-2015 heating seasons. Building's energy performance was improved by about 60%. Official opening ceremony was held on September 19, 2014.
Based on the proven success of the Project's pilots, especially thermal retrofit of operating residential building in Avan, scaling-up of the project's pilot component is underway with negotiations on co-financing held, particularly, with European Investment Bank.
The issues of delayed construction of a pilot building in Akhuryan community are pending their executive solution by the Ministry of Urban Development.
The Memorandum of Understanding is signed with Ministry of Urban Development, and UNECE on development of Armenia Housing Country Profile and Goris Smart City Concept. The project supported and participated in seminars held by UNECE in Goris town on February and April.
Awareness of the Project partners and interested developers was raised via continuous consultations and support in revision of their design documents.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
To secure long-term financial sustainability of the Armenian PA system
Area of sustainably financed PAs

comment.narrative: 100,000 ha cat. I-II by 2013 300,000 ha cat. I-IV by 2016 [original targets] at least 200,000 ha cat. I-V by 2016, which represents over 80% of the all PA category I-V hectares excluding Lake Sevan [the revised target as advised by the MTR and approved by the PEB]

177,746 ha cat. I-V
During the reporting year, CNF signed an agreement for co-financial support with Gnishik Community Protected Landscape (6,010 ha). As such, 67% of all land under formal Cat. I-V Protection has improved financial sustainability.

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative: 29% (excluding non-recurring donor funding)

54% [original target]
40%
(as revised by PEB based on MTR recommendation]

$ 517,000 was disbursed by CNF in 2014, less than the planned target of $ 607,190, due to limited absorption and decision making capacities of the relevant PA management authorities.
During 2015, CNF plans to disburse $ 516,620. As of June 30, 2015, CNF factually disbursed $ 359,076, on track to meet the 2015 target.
Government funding to CNF-supported PAs in 2014 in AMD increased by 10% compared to 2013.
A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio by means of the Financial Scorecard will be completed for the TE in 2017.

description.narrative: Critical ecosystems of protected areas providing habitats for endemic and endangered species are conserved

comment.narrative: Ecosystems are deteriorating

Habitats in 4-5 Category 1-2 PAs are conserved by 2013 [original target]
Habitats in 6-7 Cat I-V PAs are conserved by 2016 [revised by PEB as recommended by MTR.]

CNF continues established practice of providing co-financial support to 6 Cat I-V PAs: salary top-ups, equipment and running costs, with additional TA support for accounting, budgeting, planning and procurement.
A pilot biodiversity monitoring program was initiated in â€œKhosrov Forestâ€ PA, targeting Bezoar goat, Bear, Leopard, Lynx, Wolf, and Cinereous vulture species.
CNF in cooperation with WWF Armenia initiated the implementation of a Red deer reintroduction project in Dilijan NP.

description.narrative: Ensuring sufficiency and predictability of revenue sources for the PA system
Reduce annual funding gap by $440,000 by 2013

comment.narrative:
49% of basic funding
29% of optimal funding

78% of basic funding
47% of optimal funding
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap by $ 517,000; for 2015 the projection is $ 516,620. As of June 30, 2015, actual expenditure in 2015 was $ 359,076, on track to reach the 2015 target.

description.narrative: US$ value of capitalization of sinking fund.

comment.narrative: Technically speaking, the value of the GEF Sinking Fund (SFAF1) is still $1,000,000, since no additional donations to this particular sinking fund were made. Meanwhile CNF has received significant donations outside the sinking fund. To give a sense of the reality of the project, CNF reports $4,267,764 (taking into account GEF funding plus 1/3 of Euro 12 million funding from BMZ plus private donations). We are therefore significantly above the target of $2,435,000. To December 2014 we spent overall $2 million in the PAs and plan a further $560,000 in 2015, reaching our total spending target of $2,435,000. In addition to this funding we have received a further EUR 5 million into the endowment, putting us on target for a long term funding capacity of $650,000 pa.

description.narrative: Number of PAs financed from CPAF

comment.narrative: CPAF is currently not financing any PAs
Four to five PAs financed by 2013

CNF continued providing co-financial support to 6 Cat I-V PAs: Khosrov Forest, Zangezur (legal successor of both Arevik and Shikahogh PAs), Arzakan-Meghradzor, Dilijan, Lake Arpi, and Gnishik Community Managed PA.

No NRM guidance exists today.
0
0

Context adapted Guidance on NRM developed, on-line training made available
2
Modest
Indicator no longer valid following request by Senior beneficiary and recommended by MTR, as approved by PEB

description.narrative: Long-term annual funding capacity of CPAF available for Armenia based on its endowment, sinking fund and other regular annual commitments.

comment.narrative:
$950,000 (original target)
$650,000
(revised by the PEB following recommendation of the MTR).

In 2014, CNFâ€™s support valued $ 517,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 516,620, on target to reach the agreed end-of-project annual target.
As of June 30, 2015, actual expenditure in 2015 was $ 359,076, on track to reach the 2015 target.

description.narrative: Raising cost-effectiveness and capacities of PAs

Increase in cost-effectiveness of at least 10 PAs measured by financial score card (part II, component II);
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs (Indicator reformulated by PEB after MTR)

comment.narrative:
0.08
No accounting system is in place at CNF-supported PAs (baseline revised by PEB after the MTR).

0.33 (original target)
An accounting system is in place at CNF-supported PAs (target revised by PEB after the MTR).
An accountancy software program has been installed at CNF-supported PAs, hands-on support is provided for its operationality.

description.narrative:
[original target description]: Adoption of site-specific business plans at 10 PAs providing transparency on the optimum level of management costs
[revised target description]: Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the PAs covered by CNF (revised target description)

comment.narrative: 10 business plans adopted (original target) Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the 4 to 5 PAs covered by CNF (target revised by the PEB after the MTR).
During the reporting period, guided by CNFâ€™s PA Management Support Group, 5 PA Budget & Operational Plans were developed or updated, for Lake Arpi, Dilijan, Khosrov, Zangezur, and Gnishik.

description.narrative: Number of site managers trained in cost-effective management

comment.narrative:
At least three in a minimum of 10 targeted PAs [original target]
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs [target revised by the PEB after the MTR]

CNF engaged a full-time budgeting & procurement consultant to provide on-the-job, hands-on and help-desk support to PAs on financial and budgeting issues, particularly on accounting, procurement and reporting procedures, based on the accountancy software and training provided to the PAs by TJS.

description.narrative: Existence of electronic system to track changes in management effectiveness based on the METT score and - where appropriate - on the Financial Sustainability Scorecard.

comment.narrative: No such system exists
Development and implementation of such a system
Preparation of updated METT Scorecard(s) is planned for 2016, in preparation for the projectâ€™s TE.

description.narrative: Preparation of the Third National Communication to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.

To respond to the objectives of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in accordance with its commitments as a Party to the Convention mandated by Articles 4 and 12 of the UNFCCC and subsequent Conference of Parties (COP) decisions.
capital of a political entity

1. Availability of Third National Communication on Climate Change 1.1. Availability of the Greenhouse Gas Inventory Report 1.2. Availability of the adaptation project proposals 1.3. Availability of the mitigation project proposals 2. Level of public outreach on climate change issues

comment.narrative: 1. Second National Communication submitted in 2010 (2010) 1.1. Greenhouse Gas Inventory was submitted in 2010 (2010) 1.2. Adaptation project proposals were formulated in 2010 (2010) 1.3. Mitigation project proposals were formulated in 2010 (2010) 2. Lower level of awareness raising on climate change issues (2010)

1. Third National Communication is finalized, published and submitted to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 1.1. Finalized in 2014 1.2. Adaptation project proposals formulated 1.3. Mitigation project proposals formulated 2. Awareness raising events arranged, project web-page regularly updated

1. The TNC draft was presented to the Inter-agency Council on climate change. The approved Third National Communication (TNC) was submitted to UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 1.1. Finalized in 2014 1.2. One adaptation project proposal is formulated 1.3. Working group for development of the concept of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDC) is established Grid Emission Factor Standardized Baseline of Armenia was calculated and formally submitted to the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) Executive Board (EB). Project proposal concept on mitigation in residential sector is developed. 2. 5 round tables, 5 press clubs and 26 interviews were organized; 1 film produced

description.narrative: The overarching goal of the project is to save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing energy efficiency of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies

The overarching goal of the project is to save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing energy efficiency of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: To save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing the energy efficiency (EE) of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via the implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies.

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: To save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing the energy efficiency (EE) of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via the implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies.

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: To save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing the energy efficiency (EE) of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via the implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation
To remove barriers to energy-efficient lighting in Armenia, by means of technical assessment, facilitation of financing, and development and implementation of municipal programs and national policy
Quantity of energy saved and GHG emissions avoided.

comment.narrative:
Street lighting: 40 GWh of electricity consumed for street lighting in 2011, accounting for about 16,000 tons of CO2 emissions.
Average fixture power consumption is 210W in 2011.
Residential lighting: 550 GWh consumed for residential lighting in 2011, accounting for about 220,000 tons of CO2 emissions.

Direct energy savings of 1.2 GWh per year from demonstration projects (474 tonnes of CO2 emissions)
Indirect energy savings of 20 GWh per year from replication of demonstration projects via municipal programs (8000 tonnes of CO2 emissions)
Indirect energy savings of 125 GWh per year from implementation of national lighting policy (50,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions)

Direct energy savings achieved within the reporting period from demonstration projects is 127.6 MWh (9.1%) and 56.6 tonnes of CO2 emissions.
Indirect energy saving from replication of demonstration projects is expected to be achieved within the next reporting period.
Indirect energy saving from implementation of national lighting policy is expected to be achieved by the end of the project.

description.narrative: Municipal energy audits and technical capacity-building

Methodology for energy/lighting audit
Number of municipal energy audits conducted
Number of specialists and agency representatives trained
Public media exposure

comment.narrative:
Lack of methodology for assessing the feasibility (financial and technical) of an energy efficient lighting technology upgrade
Comprehensive energy audits are not part of normal practice for public lighting in Armenia
No specialized training on EE lighting is offered in Armenia
Limited broadcasting of information on EE lighting

By the project midterm the methodology will be established and shared with municipalities
At least 10 comprehensive audits of public lighting completed in Yerevan and other cities
Training on EE lighting delivered to specialists and agency representatives in Yerevan and at least 10 other cities
Media releases on outcomes of each pilot. Awareness raising materials available for general public

The methodology was developed and tested during energy audit in Yerevan city (demo site), Alaverdi, Stepanavan, Spitak and Goris towns. Total: 5 audits.
30 specialists were trained of Yerevan Municipal Illumination Company and respective municipalities on proper installation and operation and maintenance of light-emitting diodes (LED) luminaires.
Seminar on technical regulation of lighting devicesâ€™ application and establishment of national testing laboratory was held by a specialists of a partner to the project, "Center of LED and optoelectronic technologies of National Academy of Sciences of Belarus" (50 participants).
Awareness raising materials prepared and disseminated, including sharing during relevant events.

description.narrative: Demonstration projects Pilot projects yield cost-effective energy savings, raising the confidence and capacity of investors and decision-makers about EE lighting

Efficiency and energy savings of installed EE lighting
Share of LED in demo-projects

comment.narrative:
The majority of fixtures in municipal outdoor lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250W HPS lamps or 400W mercury-vapor lamps.
The indoor lighting sector is dominated by inefficient incandescent lamps and fluorescent tubes.

At least five demonstration projects on a number of efficient lighting technologies completed for indoor, outdoor and street lighting.
Direct energy savings of up to 0.95 GWh per year by completion of all pilots (subject to final selection of pilot size and technologies); 100% LED for outdoor (park) and indoor lighting pilots; 40% LED included in street lighting pilots.

3 demonstration projects are completed.
In Yerevan, 482 street LED luminaires were procured and installed on the road connecting the city's center with Zvartnots international airport (9 km), replacing high pressure sodium lamps with 63% energy efficiency improvement.
In Yerevan Zoological Garden, 115 park LED luminaires were procured and installed as a part of full reconstruction of the lighting system.
In Alaverdi, 70 street LED were installed with 55 procured by the project and 15 - by the partner NGO, French-Armenian interprofessional network.
100% LED replacement is achieved in all the three implemented demonstration projects.

description.narrative:
Replication via municipal programs and associated financial instruments.
Municipal lighting programs lead to widespread deployment of EE lighting and associated energy savings.

Municipal programs for EE public lighting.
Financial commitments for energy-efficient municipal lighting.

comment.narrative: Municipal programs for EE public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented.

Municipality of Yerevan develops and adopts program for upgrades of municipal lighting.
Similar programs are adopted in other cities of Armenia.
Savings of 20 GWh per year from municipal lighting programs.
US $10 million for energy-efficient municipal lighting secured.
EstablishÂ¬ment of financing mechanisms for Yerevan and other municipalities (e.g. revolving fund) from savings achieved from piloted EE measures.
Support in preparation of funding proposals (including tenders for ESCOs) for cities of Armenia.

Municipal programs for Alaverdi, Spitak, Goris and Stepanavan towns are drafted. Alaverdi and Spitak drafts are shared with the owner municipalities for comments and further approval.
Revolving fund concept, operation procedure and financial flow estimation methodology are developed, discussed, approved and at work in Yerevan. In Alaverdi, the revolving fund concept is under consideration.

description.narrative: National policies, codes, and standards on lighting New national policies mandate significantly greater energy efficiency and ensure product quality for lighting, particularly in residential buildings
Existence of regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations, including codes, standards, and pro-curement rules

comment.narrative:
Conventional incandescent lighting is available without restrictions and consti-tutes 85 percent of residential lighting in Armenia
There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia

Proposed improvement to existing legislation addressing minimum energy performance requirements for lighting appliances
A national phase-out plan of convenÂ¬tional incandescent lighting is adopted
Other adopted policies and supporting standards
New criteria (including performance and life cycle costs) for incorporation in state procurement procedures for lighting applications are developed

The energy labeling procedure, economy sector identification by its energy-intensity concept for further use in statistics and a number of other amendments after discussion were included in the amendments to the RA Law "On Renewable Energy and Energy Saving", currently pending adoption by the National Assembly of the RA.
The decision of RA Government, as developed by the project, â€œOn implementation of energy saving and energy efficiency improvement measures in objects being constructed (reconstructed, renovated) under the state fundingâ€ was approved by the Government of the RA (decision #1504-N of December 25, 2014).
International experience on phase-out of inefficient incandescent lamps was studied and a respective analytical note was elaborated, including an address to legal and regulatory issues.

description.narrative: Elimination of Obsolete Pesticide Stockpiles and Addressing Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) Contaminated Sites within a Sound Chemicals Management Framework

The objective of the project is to protect human health and the environment locally through elimination of POPs and obsolete pesticide stockpiles, and addressing associated contaminated sites within a sound chemicals management framework.

Mainstreaming Sustainable Land and Forest Management in Dry Mountain Landscapes of Northeastern Armenia

Sustainable land and forest management in the Northeastern Armenia secures continued flow of multiple ecosystem services (water provision, land slide control and carbon storage and sequestration) and ensures conservation of critical wildlife habitats.

comment.narrative: 1. Representation and meaningful participation of women in decision making is low (2015) 2. During 2016, local elections will be held in 118 communities of Syunik and Vayots Dzor Marzes. Only 2% of the village community leaders are females (2015) 3. In average, women representation in local self-government is 9.3% (2015) 4. The Territorial Administration Reform implies major community enlargement, which is sensitive and challenging process, including for women (2015) 5.
